title: Russet Potato Rinsing, Cubing, and Storage Techniques

items.name: Rinse before cubing
items.details: Always rinse russet potatoes after peeling and before cubing (or before peeling if leaving skin on). Removes surface dirt and grit.

items.name: Cubing method
items.details: Peel, then slice a flat side so it does not roll. Cut into 3/4 to 1 inch slabs, stack and cut into sticks, then rotate and cut crosswise into cubes. Drop immediately into cold water to prevent browning.

items.name: Ideal stew cube size
items.details: 3/4 to 1 inch cubes. Big enough to stay intact during a long simmer, small enough to cook through evenly.

items.name: Sizing russets
items.details: Medium russet is about 5-7 oz. Large russet is about 10-12+ oz. 2 large russets equal roughly 4 medium.

items.name: Short-term storage for cut potatoes
items.details: Submerge completely in cold water in a sealed container in the fridge. Keeps 24-48 hours. Pat dry before cooking.

items.name: Freezing cut potatoes
items.details: Peel, cube, blanch in boiling water for 2 minutes, transfer to ice water for 3-5 minutes until fully cooled, drain well, freeze individually on a baking sheet for 30-60 minutes, then transfer to a freezer bag. Lasts 2-3 months.

items.name: Using frozen potatoes
items.details: Toss straight into soups, stews, or breakfast potatoes. No thawing needed.

notes: Cold water prevents oxidation (browning) and draws out starch for cleaner broth. Always blanch before freezing for best results. Potato skins do not freeze well once cut.
